newsitem.title: UK: European physicals slow, March needs covered.
newsitem.headline: European physicals slow, March needs covered.

text.p: European base metal physical business continued to run at a low ebb, with most users having covered their requirements for this month, traders said on Thursday.
In some cases the ongoing high prices on the London Metal Exchange (LME) deterred all but essential hand-to-month buying.
But currency factors, notably for Continental users, were also restricting interest, with enquiries often resulting in no business being booked, they said.
"German consumers have a problem because in mark terms tin is around 10.00 marks/kilo, which they see as high," one trader said.
That meant the residual 10 percent of business not tied up in long-term contracts and usually done on the spot market was just not taking place at present.
Spot premiums for tin remained around $30/40 for Chinese and Indonesian metal.
Similar conditions were seen in aluminium, where recent rises on the LME have stifled spot interest, but premiums remained fully steady, aluminium traders said.
"Since the start of March the physical market has gone very quiet," one said.
But looking ahead, premiums could well push up some $10 towards the latter half of March, due to covering against April positions.
Traders said there was very little Russian off-grade aluminium in Europe, with this metal largely moving across the Atlantic to take advantage of high U.S. spot premiums.
Russian A6 and A5 aluminium was indicated around $25/35 and $20/30 premium respectively.
Copper physicals continued slow, with the nearby contango and a narrower overall backwardation not yet prompting trade.
"It is almost as if people do not expect it (the cash/March contango) to last," one trader said.
Western cathodes continued to hold around $20/30 premium, while Russian discounts remained some $20/30.
